item.title: UGREEN’s USB-C Cables Hit Record Lows Across All Sizes, Time to Stock Up Thanks to an Amazon Deal
item.content:encoded:
You really can’t have too many USB cables, can you? And now that Apple finally in the last couple years went ahead and ditched its proprietary Lightning cable to join the rest of the world in using the USB-C standard, you have even more reason to have USB-C cables readily available in every room in your house. UGREEN is well established brand in the field of charging accessories, and right now, Amazon has a number of their cables on sale for as much as 42% off.

The UGREEN USB-C to USB-C 100W cable comes in four different sizes and your choice of buying them individually or as a pair. Breaking down the various options, we first have the smallest 1.6ft cable which only is available in a bundle of two. That normally goes for $17, but has come down to just $13. Going a size up, we have the 3.3ft cables which you can get on for $7 (down from $12) or two for $7 (down from $13). That should be a no brainer on whether to get one or two. Doubling the length to 6.6ft, you can the single for $8 ( down from $10) or $2 for $14 (down from $17). Lastly, we have the super long 10ft option which you can either get one of for $10 (down from $14) or two of for $18 (down from $23).

See at Amazon

One of those long 10ft ones are great to keep in your living room. This way no matter where you or a guest is sitting on your couch, they’ll be able to charge their phone while keeping it comfortably on their person, instead of needing to return to a different corner of the room to check for messages every 15 minutes. These cables are threaded with nylon braiding too, so they’re less susceptible to fraying or splitting.

Wide Compatibility

As a USB-C cable, this has a broad range of compatibility for various devices. It can be used to charge laptops like the new MacBook Pros, cell phones like the iPhone 17/16/15 Series, Samsung S25/S24/S23, and Google Pixel, as well as the newly released Nintendo Switch 2.

The UGREEN USB-C cable is equipped with smart chip protection. It’s built with an E-marker which can intelligently match the required current while increasing charging efficiency. It’s 100W so it’s capable of ultra-fast charging with PD3.0 and QC3.0 tech. You can expect to be able to bring an iPhone 17 Pro Max from dead to 50% in just 20 minutes time.

As a USB-C cable, it’s also capable of data transfer. You’ll be able to send and receive files at transfer speeds of up to 480Mbps, allowing you to quickly move massive files like movies or entire photo libraries in no time flat.

item.title: Samsung Goes All-In on Its 32″ Odyssey Gaming Monitor With 42% Off, Making It Cheaper Than the 27″ Model
item.content:encoded:
A monitor can make or break your gaming experience. If you’re looking to enjoy consistent, high-quality visuals and snappy performance for your favorite titles, you need a solid option in your gaming setup.

Samsung makes some of the best out there, and we just found a way to grab one of its top-rated screens for less. The 32-inch Samsung Odyssey G50D Series is currently going for $250 at Amazon, after the retailer generously slashed a whopping 42% off its price. This is one of the lowest prices we have seen in a while, but there’s a catch. The discount ends soon, so there isn’t much time left to save. It’s best to snap it up as quickly as you can!

See at Amazon

Brighter Whites, Deeper Blacks

For just $250, you’re getting a spacious 32-inch screen. Expect lifelike visuals with QHD resolution that packs in 1.7 times the pixel density of Full HD for better detail and sharper images. The fast IPS panel offers exceptional color accuracy, while the wide 178-degree viewing angle makes it easy to enjoy consistent visuals from nearly every side; you don’t have to sit exactly at the front of the screen to see what’s going on, which also makes it great for multiplayer matches with friends.

VESA DisplayHDR 400 support offers more contrast, helping you see all the shades better. Think brighter whites and deeper blacks, with even the shadows being visible. Translation? You will be able to spot enemies hidden in the dark easily, plus enjoy better contrast overall. The monitor also comes with an eye saver mode that actively minimizes blue light to help keep your eyes relaxed when gaming for extended periods.

As for the performance, the 180Hz refresh rate does an excellent job of eliminating lag, resulting in ultrasmooth action, even during those fast-paced games. A 1ms response time, on the other hand, reduces blur, making it easy to jump on enemies as soon as you spot them. Additionally, the AMD Radeon FreeSync keeps your monitor and graphics card refresh rate in sync for an even more immersive experience, whether you’re just streaming a show or teaching bad guys a lesson.

Samsung G50D can also be freely moved to accommodate the way you play. You can adjust the height, swivel, and tilt it to find the right viewing angle for a competitive edge. Sitting upright for an intense battle? Position it straight. Feeling tired of sitting and want to game while standing? That’s possible too.

In short, if you’ve been looking to enjoy better visuals that make you feel like a part of the action, the Samsung G50D is an excellent option to consider. It offers impressive detail, vibrant colors, and a solid refresh rate – all of which come together to deliver an immersive gaming experience. The monitor is now going for $250, down from $430, which makes today a great time to pick it up for less. If the 32-inch version is bigger than what you’re after, there’s also a 27-inch version of the same model. It’s going for $250, too, after a 29% discount. However, considering how the 32-inch version offers more in the same price, it’s definitely a better pick.

See at Amazon

item.title: Here’s Why Pokémon Sun And Moon Is The Only One I’ve Never Finished
item.content:encoded:
I try not to have a backlog. I’m choosier with what I spend time on at this stage of my life than I used to be, and if I care enough to play a game, I usually see it through. But there is one white whale on my shelf that, despite multiple attempts, I’ve never been able to commit to seeing through: Pokémon Sun and Moon, as well as their enhanced re-release, Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon. The reason why is…a lot more stupid than you’d probably expect.

With the exception of the Alola games, I have finished every mainline Pokémon game at least once. I played through the first three generations endlessly on loop as a kid, creating new challenges for myself and catching new monsters to make the most of the game for as long as I could. It wasn’t until Generation IV that I became a “one and done” Pokémon player before moving on to the next thing. This was both because I was old enough to buy more games for myself so I wasn’t constantly pulling water from the stone, and because I was starting to lose interest in the stories they were telling. 

Pokémon games have had cool worldbuilding but lackluster narrative, so as I was getting older and playing grander RPGs like Mass Effect, Pokémon wasn’t holding my attention the way it once had. But still, I was playing these games as if out of obligation. I finished them, put them on my shelf, and didn’t think about them much beyond that. So what could have possibly happened with Sun and Moon and their “definitive” editions that finally pushed me over the edge and made me not finish a Pokémon game? Let me tell you about my pancake-eating archnemesis, Alolan Raichu.

Kotaku readers will know that Raichu, the evolved form of Pikachu, is my favorite Pokémon. Because his little brother is the mascot of the whole dang franchise, Raichu is often forgotten, and sometimes, in the case of the anime, actively set up for failure to make Pikachu look good. 

For many years, I grinned and bore it. To me Pikachu, Raichu, and their pre-evolution, Pichu, were all the same Pokémon anyway. If one form got love, it was like my partner in crime was getting attention at different stages of his life. But man, Game Freak was adamant about making sure everyone and their mother knew that Raichu was the red-headed stepchild of the family. Pikachu has a held item that makes it more powerful than Raichu, so there’s even a mechanical reason not to use a Thunder Stone and evolve it. Raichu’s Ultra Moon Pokedex entry even says, “Because so many Trainers like the way Pikachu looks, you don’t see this Pokémon very often.” Relax, Game Freak.

So when Sun and Moon was coming out, I was already halfway off the wagon. Then it arrived and Game Freak revealed that every Pikachu in the game would evolve into a new regional variant. The Alolan version of Raichu is…cute, I guess. It gains the psychic typing which lets it levitate and surf around on its tail, and all of this is apparently a result of Pikachu overeating Alolan pancakes, which is why it emits a sweet scent when it rubs its electric cheeks. But I saw through its facade. I don’t smell maple syrup, I smell some bullshit. I want to fistfight him in the streets.

Behind this syrup-smelling surfing psychic’s cute round face is a nasty, vile truth: Game Freak and The Pokémon Company were only willing to give Raichu attention if they changed him into something else entirely. The boy cannot get respect in his own form, and that has only become more clear in the years since Sun and Moon. Pikachu gets a Gigantamax form in Sword and Shield, an exclusive Z-Move in Sun and Moon, and is always the playable version in games like Pokken Tournament and Pokémon Unite. Raichu, meanwhile, gets scraps…unless it’s the Alolan variant, which is featured in games like Super Smash Bros. Ultimate and is playable in Pokémon Unite. 

A lot of this disrespect and preferential treatment has come after Sun and Moon, but I still called Alolan Raichu for what it was. Sun and Moon was already primed to push me away with its less interesting tropical setting and a Pokedex with too few standouts to keep me hunting for new favorites, so to not even be able to explore this region with my favorite electric rat? To be told to settle for an imposter that smells of hotcakes and psychic power? I just couldn’t push through. And y’all, I have tried so many times over the past 10 years. However, maybe I can finally go back after Pokémon Legends: Z-A.

The latest RPG in the series finally gives Raichu his due. He has not one, but two Mega Evolutions now, after having been oddly overlooked when X and Y came out and first introduced those transformations. I’m obsessed with both of these forms, though I have a preference for the flying, physical-attacking X form. I admit, however, there is some part of me that still feels a little bit of that lingering resentment because both forms carry distinct visual similarities to Pikachu, almost as if Game Freak wanted to make a Mega Pikachu but couldn’t based on their own rules, and so my rat son finally got love. Yes, Alolan Raichu felt like a slight to us OG Raichu lovers at the time…but now that my favorite Pokémon finally isn’t being ignored, do I have it in me to forgive the dopey-ass surfer boy for his crimes?

As the resident Pokémon guy around these parts, Sun and Moon is one of the only examples I have of a backlog game that feels truly wrong to have not seen through to the end. Usually, if I don’t finish a game, there’s a less stupid and prideful reason like I just wasn’t enjoying it, so I don’t carry the baggage of games left incomplete on my shoulders as I head out to new worlds on unknown adventures. But I’m a certified champion in every other Pokémon region besides Alola, which I left unconquered mostly because I didn’t want to do it without my best friend by my side. I might not go back any time soon, but for the first time in over a decade, I’m starting to feel like I’m letting go of the pride that has kept me from seeing it through.

item.title: TP-Link’s Wi-Fi 6 Router Is Back at a Record Low After a Weekend Price Hike, and This Dual-Band Mesh System Works With Alexa
item.content:encoded:
How old is your home Wi-Fi router? Take this post as a notice that it might be time for an upgrade. TP-Link is one of the best in the business, and right now Amazon happens to have its Archer AX21 Wi-Fi 6 router on sale for a hefty 35% discount. The router is usually priced at $80, but has come down to just $52 for a limited time. That means you’ll be saving a cool $28 which you can go spend on V-bucks or something to grab the new Eric Cartman skin in Fortnite.

This dual-band Wi-Fi router is able to achieve super fast speeds, with greater capacity and reduced network congestion compared to its older model. You’ll be able to enjoy smoother online gaming and more stable streaming, as well as reach download speeds of up to 1.8Gbps in total bandwidth. The 5GHz band supports up to 1,200Mbps while the 2.4Ghz supports another 574 Mbps. Of course, your exact performance may vary based on a number of factors including distance between devices and obstacles such as walls.

See at Amazon

The TP-Link router has four Ethernet LAN ports, so you can connect all your devices on which you need the best, uninterrupted internet connections. Plug in your gaming PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X, and your Nintendo Switch 2. That’s your four right there. Additionally, more than 40 devices can be connected over Wi-Fi at once.

Build Your Own Mesh Network

This is an EasyMesh compatible unit—meaning you can use this as your main router for network onboarding and management. Then combine it with either other EasyMesh compatible routers or range extenders to turn your home network into a mesh network. This can result in better coverage and fewer (hopefully no) dead spots throughout your house or apartment. Mesh networks will intelligently switch your Wi-Fi-enabled devices from one node to the next as it detects it moving throughout your home. As in, you’re going from downstairs to upstairs with your phone in your pocket, it’ll switch over which router its connected to based on proximity. Each router will also share the same Wi-Fi name so no extra confusion there.

The TP-Link Archer AX21 router is listed as working with Amazon Alexa. However, not much info is provided on what exactly you can do with Alexa with it. I do find it mildly amusing to be like, “Alexa, disconnect Derek’s PS5 from the Wi-Fi,” while your kid brother is about to get his very first Victory Royale. Again, though, not sure if that’s possible.

See at Amazon

item.title: Amazon Clears Out 15.6″ Portable Monitor at Record Low After 10K+ Sold, Double Your Productivity and Screen Real Estate for Less
item.content:encoded:
We’re already more than halfway through January. What kind of changes have you been implementing to actually hit some of your 2026 goals? Perhaps you have high hopes of getting into better shape, eating healthier, maybe you’re aiming to learn a new skill. If your big plans are just to be more productive than ever before, you might want to take a look at your work setup. most of us are happy just working off a laptop, but you’re really limiting your potential by sticking with such little screen real estate. A portable monitor can go a long way, and this one from MNN happens to be seeing a major discount right now. Normally priced at $59, it’s come down to an even $50 for a limited time.

Remote work has allowed many of us the flexibility to step outside our homes and get work done from anywhere we please, be it a coffee shops, library, or even a hotel room. Although, a change of environment can introduces a drawback. You’re now stuck working off just you’re laptop, instead of your elaborate multi-screen desktop home setup I’m assuming you must have. Managing emails, documents, spreadsheets, and video calls on a single laptop screen means all those windows are fighting for the same bit of space. A portable monitor addresses this issue by providing an additional display, closely mimicking the comfort and efficiency of your home setup wherever you happen to be working.

See at Amazon

The MNN 15.6-inch portable monitor is built with mobile professionals in mind. Its large display makes it easier to view and manage multiple apps at once. It has an HD resolution of 1080p and render color brightly and accurately.

Getting started is simple and straightforward. The monitor connects through either of its two USB-C ports, ensuring compatibility with a wide variety of devices. In addition to laptops, it can be used with smartphones, desktop PCs, PlayStation and Xbox consoles, and even a Nintendo Switch.

Built for Travel

With an ultra-slim profile measuring just 0.3 inches thin and 1.52 lbs., the monitor fits easily into a backpack or laptop bag without adding extra weight or bulk. It also comes with a scratch-resistant smart cover made from durable PU leather, providing extra protection while traveling. The cover doubles as a stand using a frameless magnetic design, allowing the monitor to be positioned in either landscape or portrait mode. Choose the orientation that best matches your workflow, whether you’re writing, coding, or scrolling through lengthy documents. Sometimes it’s nice to just have your Slack chats positioned vertically on the second display, while you’re getting your actual work done in front of you on your laptop screen.
